title: Lesson 17: The Cellular Basis of Disease
moduleTitle: Cells as the Basis of Life
description: Understanding how defects in cellular structures cause disease including cystic fibrosis, cancer, and mitochondrial disorders. Integration of multiple cellular concepts.
learningIntentions: Students can explain how defects in specific cellular structures cause disease (cystic fibrosis, cancer, mitochondrial disease).
Students can analyse how multiple organelle/system failures interact in disease states.
Students can apply knowledge of cell biology to interpret clinical scenarios.

successCriteria: I can explain how a faulty channel protein causes cystic fibrosis.
I can describe how failure of cell cycle checkpoints leads to cancer.
I can link a mitochondrial disorder to specific cellular energy failure.

engagementHook.title: When Cells Go Wrong
engagementHook.content: 'Every disease has a cellular signature. In cystic fibrosis, it's a missing channel. In cancer, it's runaway division. In mitochondrial disorders, it's power failure. Today we diagnose three patients by looking through the microscope at their cellular machinery.'

keyConcepts.definition: Mutation in CFTR protein (channel protein in membrane—Lesson 9). Channel fails to transport chloride ions. Water follows by osmosis (Lesson 10). Results in thick mucus blocking lungs/pancreas. Connects membrane structure → transport → osmosis → clinical outcome.

Mutations in checkpoint genes (p53, from Lesson 11). Cells divide uncontrollably (mitosis without regulation). Tumour formation. Metastasis involves loss of cell adhesion (cell membrane glycoproteins—Lesson 9).
Mutations in mitochondrial DNA (Lesson 7). Energy failure in high-demand tissues (muscle, brain). Maternal inheritance (only egg provides mitochondria).
Single protein defect → organelle dysfunction → cellular failure → tissue disease → organ failure.

misconceptions.correction: Cancer is many diseases characterised by uncontrolled cell division; different cancers involve different mutations.
Affects any organ with epithelial cells using CFTR (pancreas, digestive tract, sweat glands).

misconceptions.misconception: Mitochondrial diseases affect all cells equally
misconceptions.correction: High-energy tissues (brain, muscle) affected most severely.

contentSections.title: Patient A - Thick Mucus (Cystic Fibrosis)
contentSections.content: CFTR channel defect (membrane protein). Chloride can't exit cell. Osmotic water flow reversed (water stays in cell/decreased). Mucus dehydrated and thick. Bacterial infections result (blocked airways).
contentSections.example: Link to prior: Lesson 9 (channel proteins), Lesson 10 (osmosis).
contentSections.checkForUnderstanding: Is this a problem with the membrane structure or the transport process? (Both—faulty protein affects transport.)

contentSections.title: Patient B - Uncontrolled Growth (Cancer)
contentSections.content: Checkpoint failure (p53 mutation from Lesson 11). No G1/S arrest when DNA damaged. Mutations accumulate. Mitosis continues unchecked. Loss of contact inhibition (cells keep dividing when touching).
contentSections.example: Link to prior: Lessons 11-12 (cell cycle control).
contentSections.checkForUnderstanding: Which phase checkpoint has failed if cells enter mitosis with damaged DNA? (G2/M checkpoint.)

contentSections.title: Patient C - Muscle Weakness (Mitochondrial Myopathy)
contentSections.content: mtDNA mutation → defective electron transport chain (Lesson 7). ATP production drops. Muscle cells (high energy demand) weaken. Lactic acid builds up (anaerobic respiration).
contentSections.checkForUnderstanding: Why are muscle and brain cells most affected? (Highest energy demand.)

activities.title: Connect Disease to Cellular Defect
activities.description: Match each disease to its primary cellular defect.

activities.title: Predict Cellular Consequences
activities.description: Predict the consequences of blocking the sodium-potassium pump.
activities.text: A drug blocks the sodium-potassium pump in nerve cells. Two cellular consequences would be: (1) Loss of [[membrane potential]] affecting nerve signalling; (2) Inability to import glucose via [[cotransport]]; (3) Potential [[cell swelling]] due to osmotic water influx.

multipleChoice.question: Cystic fibrosis results from a defect in:
options: A channel protein in the cell membrane
multipleChoice.correctAnswer: A channel protein in the cell membrane
multipleChoice.rationale: CFTR is a channel protein that transports chloride ions.

multipleChoice.question: Uncontrolled cell division in cancer is most likely caused by failure of:
multipleChoice.rationale: Checkpoints prevent uncontrolled division. When they fail, damaged cells continue to divide.

multipleChoice.question: Why do mitochondrial diseases primarily affect muscle and brain tissue?
options: These tissues have the most cells
These tissues have the highest energy demands
multipleChoice.correctAnswer: These tissues have the highest energy demands
multipleChoice.rationale: Energy-dependent tissues are most affected by ATP production failure.

shortAnswer.question: Explain how a defect in a membrane channel protein can lead to the symptoms of cystic fibrosis. (3 marks)
markingCriteria: 1 mark: CFTR channel fails to transport chloride ions across epithelial cell membranes
1 mark: Water transport/osmosis affected (less water leaves cell/water follows by osmosis incorrectly) → mucus becomes thick/dehydrated
1 mark: Thick mucus blocks airways/pancreatic ducts → breathing difficulties/digestive problems (clinical outcome)
shortAnswer.commonError: Describing bacterial infection as primary cause rather than secondary effect of mucus blockage.

shortAnswer.question: Describe how failure of cell cycle checkpoints can contribute to the development of cancer. (2 marks)
markingCriteria: 1 mark: Checkpoints normally ensure DNA is undamaged/cell is ready before division proceeds
1 mark: If checkpoints fail, cells with mutations/dividing too rapidly/uncontrollably continue to divide/accumulate mutations/forming tumour
shortAnswer.commonError: Saying checkpoints 'cause' cancer rather than their failure allowing cancer to develop.

definitions: Cystic fibrosis: Faulty CFTR channel → ion transport defect → thick mucus.
Cancer: Failure of cell cycle checkpoints → uncontrolled mitosis.
Mitochondrial diseases: ATP production failure → affects high-energy tissues (muscle, brain).
Disease often results from single protein/organelle dysfunction affecting whole organism.
keyPoints: CF = channel protein defect → osmotic imbalance
Systems thinking: protein → organelle → cell → tissue → organ
High-energy tissues most affected by mitochondrial disorders

shortAnswer: Cystic fibrosis results from a mutation in the CFTR gene, which codes for a chloride channel protein in epithelial cell membranes. This channel normally transports chloride ions out of cells. When defective, chloride transport is impaired, which disrupts the normal osmotic movement of water (osmosis). Less water leaves the cells, causing the mucus outside the cells to become thick and dehydrated. This thick mucus blocks airways (causing breathing difficulties and infections) and pancreatic ducts (causing digestive problems).

Cell cycle checkpoints normally act as surveillance mechanisms that ensure DNA is undamaged and the cell is ready before allowing division to proceed. If checkpoints fail (such as mutations in p53), cells with DNA damage can continue through the cell cycle and divide uncontrollably. These cells accumulate more mutations, divide rapidly without regulation, and can form tumours. The failure of checkpoints removes the 'quality control' that normally prevents damaged cells from proliferating.
